channel.title: undefined - Dietrich Ayala
channel.description: Working towards true user agency through a distributed web.

item.title: "A Foolish Consistency..."
item.description:
"A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds." - Ralph Waldo

EmersonLink
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Any Fool"
item.description: "Any fool can write code that computers can understand, a good programmer writes code a human can understand." - Martin FowlerLink
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Interesting Analogy..."
item.description: "That's where my analogy came in. In traditional IT projects, I said, ROI has been as elusive as high-school sex: "The question was always, are you going to get any?" But with web services, ROI is more like married sex: "You know you're getting it, but you're always wondering, what can we do to make it better?"Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "RDF Eye Opener"
item.description:
Great snippet from Eric van der Vlist on XML-DEV:

"RDF and its triples is really lightweight when you have the right tools to manipulate them. I like to think of them as a RDBMS with a variable geometry: each "row" (ie each subject) can have a variable number of columns (properties). It's like a RDBMS which you could populate before having written any schema, that's really very flexible and it's just a matter of using the right tool. When I use such a tool, I have a feeling of RDBMS without its straitjacket :-) ..."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "I'm Not 30 Yet!"
item.description:
"Early 30s is a great time to be alive- you're still young, but you have experience. A powerful combo.

The downside is all that weird rockstar shit you believe about yourself is well past its sell-by date, and if you haven't outgrown it by then, it starts to curdle your insides."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Why I Do Not Like Perl, in a Nutshell (via Camworld)"
item.description: "Obviously I screwed up somewhere, but I've only been using Perl since 1993, so I'm not an expert." - Anonymous Perl UserLink
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Woody Guthrie on Copyright"
item.description:
Pete Seeger, June 1967:

When Woody Guthrie was singing hillbilly songs on a little Los Angeles radio station in the late 1930s, he used to mail out a small mimeographed songbook to listeners who wanted the words to his songs, On the bottom of one page appeared the following: "This song is Copyrighted in U.S., under Seal of Copyright # 154085, for a period of 28 years, and anybody caught singin it without our permission, will be mighty good friends of ourn, cause we don't give a dern. Publish it. Write it. Sing it. Swing to it. Yodel it. We wrote it, that's all we wanted to do."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Claude (Len) Bullard Regarding the Benefits of REST (XML-DEV)"
item.description:
"I have to discard Fielding's

"unforeseen benefits" because while one can sell a car by telling the buyer it will get them laid, one doesn't write that into the contract."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Don Box - Sums up schema use in MS framework on XML-DEV"
item.description:
At this point, I believe most SOAP plumbers have conceded that XML

Schema will be the dominant type system and metadata format for interop.

How one converts from their local type system to the world of XML Schema

is a local problem that is (and should be) outside the scope of SOAP.

In MSFT-land, we do the conversion by importing XML Schema into our

runtime and making the "foreign" types look local. That technology is

broadly useful outside the scope of SOAP and/or web services, so we make

it accessible everywhere, although I'm sure there are lots of customers

who have no idea this is even in the platform.Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Gore Vidal (SF Gate)"
item.description: Once alienated, an unalienable right is apt to be forever lost, in which case we are no longer even remotely the last best hope of Earth but merely a seedy imperial state whose citizens are kept in line by SWAT teams and whose way of death, not life, is universally imitated.Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Nicholas Lehuen on Project Scope and Design"
item.description:
"My point would be the same with any other language, and

it's not rocket science : keep projects within precise functional

boundaries, and use carefully designed API whenever you have to cross those

boundaries. Don't think about building a project that spans those

boundaries, let people who know how to handle the stuff from abroad handle

it. If you're interested into changing your scope, then start a new project."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Dan Gillmor Draws a Line in the Sand"
item.description:
"Here's my message to the record industry and its allies:

I'm not a thief. I'm a customer. When you treat me like a thief, I won't be your customer.

Enough is enough."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Question: What did the instructor at the school for Kamikaze pilots say to his students?"
item.description:
Answer:

"Watch closely. I'm only going to do this once."

(Author unknown)Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Andrei Zmievski, PHP Developer"
item.description: "Programming is an art form that fights back."Link
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala

item.title: "Andrew Layman on Serialization of Null Values (SOAPBuilders)"
item.description: "If you open up a cupboard and don't find a bicycle, are the cupboard's contents different than if you opened it and didn't find an elephant?" - Andrew Layman, during a discussion of techniques for serializing null values in XMLLink
item.dc:creator: Dietrich Ayala
